title: Harry Pierce
text:
Henry Theodore Pierce (1913-1975) was a professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played for the <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Australia national team</a> and the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales team</a>. He played his club football in the <a href="NSWRFL%20Premiership">NSWRFL Premiership</a> for Sydney clubs <a href="St.%20George%20Dragons">St. George</a> and <a href="Eastern%20Suburbs%20Roosters">Eastern Suburbs</a>.
Playing career.
Pierce played for the <a href="St.%20George%20Dragons">St. George Dragons</a> for two seasons in 1932 and 1933 and for <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Eastern Suburbs</a> for eleven seasons between 1934 and 1944. He won three straight premierships between 1935 and 1937 with the Tricolours. He won his fourth premiership with the <a href="Sydney%20Roosters">Easts</a> in the <a href="1940%20NSWRFL%20season">1940 Grand Final</a>. He scored a total of 60 tries during his long and successful club career. The speedy <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions">backrower</a> also played in five test matches for Australia in 1937/38. He is listed on the "Australian Players Register" as Kangaroo No. 216. Pierce also played for City Firsts and <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales</a> on six occasions between 1937 and 1943.
While playing football, Pierce also served in the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Police%20Force">New South Wales Police Force</a> and in 2008, rugby league's centennial year in Australia, he was named as a reserve in a NSW Police team of the century. 
Death.
He died at <a href="Bondi%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Bondi, New South Wales</a> on 12 December 1975, 41 days short of his 63rd birthday.
